Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Using Covariance to Test Hypotheses about the Function and Underlying Genetic Control of Multi-component Signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to communicate effectively with other individuals is important for survival and reproduction; however, little is known about the genetics of producing communication signals. The proposed project focuses on sound (auditory) signals used in courtship in a species of fruit fly. The multiple auditory signals produced by this species are complex but their relationships to each other and genetic control of their production have not been determined. The proposed research incorporates methods from animal behavior, evolution, and genetics to better understand how conveying and receiving messages occurs in animals. This can provide insights into what messages are passed from males to females and how these messages are genetically controlled. Given the abundance of genetic knowledge in fruit flies, and how many genes are shared between flies and humans, broader connections can be made from this species to other study systems. In addition, part of the project will extend public understanding of the genetics and information content of signals through mentorship of two undergraduate students, outreach at a local high school, attendance at national scientific conferences, and development of teaching materials for high school classrooms.

Signals transmitted between individuals are often complex and contain multiple components. These components may convey the same information, in which case they are expected to evolve in concert, or they may have separate messages, which implies independent evolution. Understanding how signal components co-vary and are genetically controlled may provide insight into the messages conveyed. To address this problem, the acoustic signals of Drosophila sturtevanti will be examined using a novel approach. This species has complex mating signals, generated by male wing vibration, that stimulate females to mate. Two signal components, pulse song and beep song, will be examined for phenotypic covariance. The absence of phenotypic co-variation between the song components will support the hypothesis that the respective components contain multiple messages. In contrast, significant positive co-variation will support the hypothesis that the respective components contain the same message. Alternatively, significant negative co-variation will support the hypothesis that respective components constrain each other. In addition to phenotypic covariance, the genetic architecture of the two signal components will be assessed through quantitative trait loci (QTL) mapping using a next generation sequencing approach. The amount of co-localization of the QTLs for the signal components will determine the commonality of genetic control. Significant co-localization will imply shared genetic control and the direction of association (positive or negative) will indicate how selection pressures act on the genetically linked systems. Understanding the genetic control of associated signals is essential for elucidating mechanisms by which adaptive behavioral traits evolve and for modeling the evolution of multi-component signals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

A central question of behavioral and signal evolution is why and how complex behavioral signals evolve over time. Many organisms produce elaborate signals that are essential for attracting mates, warning others of close predators, and communicating about one's position in a hierarchy. When signals contain multiple components, the components might operate independently, may be redundant and potentially enhance each other, or may tradeoff if energetically costly. In the latter two cases, the signals evolve in concert and may share genetic control of the component parts. Thus, understanding both the messages that are sent in a complex signal and the underlying genetic control of signal production provide insights into if complex communication signals evolve in concert or independently. The goal of this project was to measure the phenotypic covariation of two signal components and assess whether they share genetic control. We measured co-variance of two courtship song components in a non-model Drosophila species, Drosophila sturtevanti. The primary song (always sung first, appears in most songs) of D. sturtevanti has a pulse structure similar to those of many Drosophila species, including D. melanogaster. The pulse song differs from other species in interpulse interval (IPI; the time between adjacent pulses). The secondary song (often found following primary song and sometimes not found at all) has a novel structure, a “beep”, that is dissimilar in sound to songs of the ~100 other species of Drosophila in which song has been described. Beeps are a tone song consisting of a sinusoidal-like progression of sound cycles without pulse structure that are often structured with higher amplitude sound cycles that fade into lower amplitude cycles. Males differ in how much they beep during courtship.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project examined how two components (pulse song and beep song) of one signal, courtship song, are controlled genetically. Due to recent methodological advances in genomics, use of non-model systems has become easier than before, allowing us to determine the portion of the genome contributing to complex courtship behaviors. By identifying the overlap, or lack thereof, of genomic regions contributing to signal production, we can understand if complex signals evolve in concert (genomic overlap) or individually (lack of overlap). To do this, we used a Multiplex Shotgun Genotype method to genotype individuals, which we combined with IPI and beep measurements, to perform quantitative trait loci (QTL) mapping in individuals that were a mixture of two different genotypes with different songs. Our mapping population, however, lacked enough recombination to produce a linkage map for QTL mapping. Nonetheless, the phenotypic measurements that resulted from this project were analyzed for the covariance of the signal components, which co-varied positively, indicating that males that sang with a better song than average in one signal component sang with a better than average song in the other as well, thus the signals may be redundant rather than trade-off. In addition, we recorded additional individuals to determine what aspects of courtship song contributed positively to mating success, finding that individuals that sang with both components were more likely to mate than individuals that only produced only one signal.

 

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts associated with this project were to mentor undergraduate researchers and complete a community outreach program. As part of the first goal, three undergraduate students were trained in animal behavior experimentation. For the second goal, the co-PI conducted community outreach programs associated with evolution in insects and diversity in sexual signals in Drosophila. The impacts of an outreach program with Girl Scouts was assessed, finding that the program positively increased participant attitudes towards insects.
